dialogue_history.content:
Analyze this financial news and estimate stock price movement probabilities.
Company: Apple Inc. (AAPL)
News Headline: Prediction: This Will Be Wall Street's First $5 Trillion Company -- and It's Not Nvidia
News Content: Change is perhaps the only certainty on Wall Street. Due to factors such as innovation, competition, mergers and acquisitions, bankruptcies, and legal judgments, the puzzle pieces that make up the largest publicly traded companies are constantly in flux.

When 2004 came to a close, ExxonMobil was the largest publicly traded company in the S&P 500, with Citigroup and General Electric also in the top 10. Today, Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT) is the only member of the end-of-2004 top 10 that's still among America's largest publicly traded companies.Image source: Getty Images.

Since the midpoint of 2023, we've witnessed Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL), Microsoft, and semiconductor colossus Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) all surpass the $3 trillion valuation plateau. Although Nvidia would seem like the surest bet to reach the psychologically important $5 trillion level given the rise of artificial intelligence (AI), a dark-horse candidate may have the clearest path to become Wall Street's first $5 trillion company.

Nvidia is battling against history, which has a flawless track record

On one hand, there's no denying that Nvidia has enjoyed a textbook operating expansion. The company's Hopper (H100) graphics processing units (GPUs) and successor Blackwell chips have been the preferred options for businesses wanting to run generative AI solutions and train large language models in their high-compute data centers.

With demand for GPUs overwhelming supply, Nvidia has been able to command $30,000 to $40,000 for its Hopper chip, which is up to four times as much as Advanced Micro Devices has charged customers for its Instinct MI300X GPU. Having otherworldly pricing power helped to push Nvidia's gross margin to as high as 78.4% last year.

While the long-term outlook for AI remains encouraging and this technology has real-world applications in most industries around the globe, Nvidia's chances of becoming Wall Street's first $5 trillion company are likely going to be thwarted by history.

Roughly three decades ago, the internet began going mainstream and offered businesses a new way to connect with potential customers. Though the internet did, eventually, alter the growth trajectory for corporate America is a positive way, it took years before businesses really understood how to harness these new sales and marketing channels.

Including the internet, every game-changing technology or innovation for 30 years has navigated its way through an early stage bubble. In simpler terms, investors have consistently overestimated how quickly a new technology/innovation would be adopted or gain widespread utility. With most companies lacking clear game plans as to how they'll maximize the return on their AI investments, it sets artificial intelligence up to be the next in a long line of bubbles.

Story Continues

Since no company has benefited more directly from the AI revolution than Nvidia, the logical expectation is that its stock would be hit the hardest. Historic precedent makes it unlikely that Nvidia ascends to a $5 trillion valuation first.Image source: Amazon.

This dark-horse candidate has a clear path to become America's largest public company

If history were to rhyme and the AI bubble bursts, it would also be bad news for Microsoft, which has been investing heavily in an artificial intelligence-driven future. Although Microsoft's operating cash flow isn't as overwhelmingly reliant on AI as Nvidia, being the first to reach a $5 trillion valuation would be a stretch.

The same can be said for Wall Street's other $3 trillion public company, Apple. Though Apple's Services segment continues to grow by a double-digit percentage, its physical device sales, including iPhone, have stagnated for two years. Apple stock is already trading at one of its priciest valuations in a decade, which leaves little room for its valuation to rise by another $1.4 trillion.

The "Magnificent Seven" component that appears to have the clearest path to a $5 trillion market cap is e-commerce juggernaut Amazon (NASDAQ: AMZN).

When most consumers and investors hear the Amazon name, they think of its dominant online marketplace. Last February, eMarketer estimated that Amazon would account for just over 40% of U.S. online retail sales in 2024. While this online retail platform has been the face of Amazon for nearly three decades, e-commerce plays a minimal role in terms of cash flow generation and operating income.

The lion's share of Amazon's growth potential (specifically growth in cash flow) originates from its ancillary operating segments, with Amazon Web Services (AWS) at the front of the pack.

Based on data from tech-analysis firm Canalys, AWS is the world's leading cloud infrastructure service platform, with an estimated 33% share of total cloud spending during the third quarter of 2024. For context, Amazon's share of spending among cloud-service providers is more than Microsoft's Azure and Alphabet's Google Cloud, combined — and these are the No's 2 and 3 in global cloud-service spending.

Even though AI has played a role in AWS's growth, enterprise spending on cloud services was growing at a steady double-digit pace long before AI became the hottest thing since sliced bread on Wall Street. With enterprise cloud-service spending still in its relatively early stages of expansion, Amazon can expect substantially higher margins from this segment to meaningfully boost its cash flow.

Beyond AWS, Amazon's advertising services and subscription services (e.g., Prime) segments are also respectively growing by double digits. Amazon's push into exclusive sporting events (Thursday Night Football and NBA streaming packages) should improve demand for advertising, as well as support its subscription pricing power.

The key point is that, unlike Microsoft and Nvidia, Amazon wouldn't be dragged down by the AI bubble bursting thanks to its abundance of other catalysts.

Lastly, Amazon remains historically inexpensive. Throughout the 2010s, investors willingly paid 23 to 37 times year-end cash flow to own shares of the company. But as of the closing bell on Jan. 10, Amazon's shares are valued at just 13.5 times consensus cash flow for 2026. If Amazon were to reach the median year-end multiple to cash flow it traded at consistently from 2010 through 2019, it would become Wall Street's first $5 trillion company.

Don’t miss this second chance at a potentially lucrative opportunity

Ever feel like you missed the boat in buying the most successful stocks? Then you’ll want to hear this.

On rare occasions, our expert team of analysts issues a “Double Down” stock recommendation for companies that they think are about to pop. If you’re worried you’ve already missed your chance to invest, now is the best time to buy before it’s too late. And the numbers speak for themselves:

Nvidia: if you invested $1,000 when we doubled down in 2009, you’d have $352,417!* Apple: if you invested $1,000 when we doubled down in 2008, you’d have $44,855!* Netflix: if you invested $1,000 when we doubled down in 2004, you’d have $451,759!*

Right now, we’re issuing “Double Down” alerts for three incredible companies, and there may not be another chance like this anytime soon.

See 3 “Double Down” stocks »

*Stock Advisor returns as of January 13, 2025

Citigroup is an advertising partner of Motley Fool Money. Suzanne Frey, an executive at Alphabet, is a member of The Motley Fool's board of directors. John Mackey, former CEO of Whole Foods Market, an Amazon subsidiary, is a member of The Motley Fool's board of directors. Sean Williams has positions in Alphabet and Amazon. The Motley Fool has positions in and recommends Advanced Micro Devices, Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Microsoft, and Nvidia. The Motley Fool recommends GE Aerospace and recommends the following options: long January 2026 $395 calls on Microsoft and short January 2026 $405 calls on Microsoft. The Motley Fool has a disclosure policy.

Prediction: This Will Be Wall Street's First $5 Trillion Company -- and It's Not Nvidia was originally published by The Motley Fool

View Comments

Next I will provide you some predictions of stock price movement probabilities and the corresponding analysis by others in the previous rounds.
Note that others' predictions may indicate that they have some other information about the stock price. A high prediction may indicate that they have some positive information about the stock, while a low prediction may indicate that they have some megative information about the stock.
Also note that there are multiple rounds of precitions, demonstrating the trend of others' beliefs.
Please take these information into consideration when prediction the stock price movement probabilities.
Previous predictions:
Round: 0
Model: openai/gpt-4o-mini, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.35, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.65, Reasoning: The article suggests that while Apple has been a competitor along with Nvidia and Microsoft in achieving high market valuations, it may be experiencing stagnation in its device sales and is trading at a high valuation. Its services segment growth is positive, but overall market dynamics might not favor a rapid increase towards a $5 trillion market cap. The discussion pivots towards Amazon as a more probable candidate for this milestone, indicating that sources of growth may be muted for Apple compared to others. Hence, the probabilities reflect a tendency for Apple’s stock price to decline slightly due to market sentiment surrounding competition and valuation concerns.
Model: google/gemini-2.0-flash-001, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.4, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.3, Reasoning: The article focuses on the potential for Amazon (AMZN) to reach a $5 trillion market cap before Apple (AAPL) or Nvidia (NVDA). While it mentions AAPL and its challenges (stagnant device sales, high valuation), it doesn't present a compelling negative argument specific to AAPL. The article suggests AAPL has less room for valuation growth. The general positive commentary on the stock market described in the “Double Down” segment suggests that there may be a small market upswing regardless of firm valuation, in which case the odds of Apple stock remaining consistent outweigh the odds that it takes a hit due to the concerns mentioned in the article. The article is more negative towards other firms discussed.
Model: google/gemini-flash-1.5, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.3, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.4, Reasoning: The article focuses on the potential for Amazon (AMZN) to become the first $5 trillion company, arguing against Nvidia and downplaying Apple's prospects.  The argument rests on several points: 1) The potential bursting of the AI bubble will negatively impact Nvidia and Microsoft, which are heavily invested in AI. 2) While Apple is strong, its valuation is already high, leaving little room for the massive growth needed to hit $5 trillion. 3) Amazon's diverse revenue streams, particularly AWS's dominant position in the cloud computing market,  give it a more sustainable growth path less reliant on the AI bubble.  4) Amazon is considered historically undervalued. The article mentions it trading at a lower cash flow multiple compared to previous valuations. This analysis suggests a positive outlook for Amazon, but it doesn't directly predict Apple's stock movement.  The overall sentiment toward Apple is neutral to slightly negative, implying a potential for sideways movement or a slight decrease due to the relative underperformance compared to Amazon according to this article's thesis.  However, this is just one article's opinion, and other factors could influence Apple’s stock price.  It's important to remember that stock prices react to many different factors, not just one news article.
Model: deepseek/deepseek-chat-v3-0324, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.55, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.45, Reasoning: The news article discusses the potential for Apple Inc. (AAPL) to become Wall Street's first $5 trillion company, but it primarily argues that Amazon (AMZN) has a clearer path due to its diverse revenue streams and growth in cloud services (AWS). While the article mentions Apple's stagnation in physical device sales and high valuation, it does not provide direct negative catalysts for Apple's stock. The focus on Amazon's potential may shift investor attention away from Apple, but there's no immediate negative impact implied. Therefore, the article's effect on Apple's stock price is likely neutral to slightly positive due to continued acknowledgment of its $3 trillion valuation and potential.
Model: meta-llama/llama-4-scout, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.3, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.7, Reasoning: The news article discusses the potential for Apple Inc. (AAPL) and other companies to reach a $5 trillion valuation. However, it suggests that Amazon (AMZN) has a clearer path to achieving this milestone due to its diversified business segments, particularly Amazon Web Services (AWS), advertising services, and subscription services. The article implies that Apple's stock is already trading at a high valuation, which leaves little room for further growth. Based on this analysis, the probability of Apple's stock price rising is lower, while the probability of it falling is higher due to the comparative analysis with Amazon.
Model: meta-llama/llama-3.3-70b-instruct, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.7, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.3, Reasoning: The news article discusses the possibility of a company reaching a $5 trillion valuation, with Amazon being considered a dark-horse candidate. The article suggests that Nvidia, despite its recent success, may not be the first to reach this milestone due to the potential for an AI bubble burst. Amazon's diverse revenue streams, including its cloud services, advertising, and subscription services, make it a more stable candidate for long-term growth. The article also notes that Amazon's current valuation is relatively low compared to its historical averages, making it an attractive investment opportunity.
Model: qwen/qwen-turbo, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.7, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.3, Reasoning: The financial news highlights a prediction that the first $5 trillion company on Wall Street will not be Nvidia but might be Amazon instead. The article suggests Amazon has strong ancillary operating segments, including AWS, which provides substantial growth potential beyond AI. Additionally, Amazon is described as historically inexpensive compared to its past multiples, suggesting room for valuation increase. These factors suggest positive developments for Amazon which might influence investors favorably.


Now give your prediction about the probability of the stock price of the relevant company rising or falling. Format your response in JSON format and include the following information as follows: 
{ 
"reasoning": "[Summarize your analysis and reasoning process here]", 
"company_name": "[Company Name indicating the name of the company]", 
"company_symbol": "[Company Symbol indicating the stock symbol of the company]", 
"news_headline": "[News Headline indicating the provided financial news headline]", 
"probability_of_stock_price_rise": [The estimated probability (a number between 0 and 1) that the stock price will rise due to this news], 
"probability_of_stock_price_fall": [The estimated probability (a number between 0 and 1) that the stock price will fall due to this news], 
} 
Do not generate output that isn't in properly formatted JSON.

```json
{
  "reasoning": "The article primarily focuses on Amazon's potential to reach a $5 trillion valuation before Apple. While it acknowledges Apple's $3 trillion valuation, it highlights concerns about stagnant device sales and a high valuation, suggesting limited room for significant growth. Several previous models reflect uncertainty, with varied probabilities of stock price increase. Given the slightly negative outlook towards Apple relative to Amazon in the article, and based on previous round results, I adjust my prediction to reflect a bit more bearish sentiment, but not much adjustment to the trend established across rounds. The news article highlights Amazon's prospects rather than Apple's, which suggests increased selling pressure on Apple stock.",
  "company_name": "Apple Inc.",
  "company_symbol": "AAPL",
  "news_headline": "Prediction: This Will Be Wall Street's First $5 Trillion Company -- and It's Not Nvidia",
  "probability_of_stock_price_rise": 0.35,
  "probability_of_stock_price_fall": 0.65
}
```
